ne_dom.title: Ne (Dominant) confirmation
ne_dom.intro: Answer based on your typical life pattern. Use 4–5 only when it’s consistently true across your life. If you choose 4–5, you can optionally tick real-life examples to confirm the pattern.

items.text: My mind naturally generates many different possibilities / paths.
examples: When a new situation appears, I immediately see several ways it could play out.
I often jump from one idea to another because each one opens more branches.
I naturally think in 'what if...' chains without trying.
I enjoy exploring multiple interpretations rather than locking into one meaning.
I get bored if there is only one allowed approach.
I can connect unrelated topics and see new angles quickly.
I frequently propose alternatives even when the current plan is fine.
I feel mentally 'stuck' if I cannot explore options.

items.text: I value open-mindedness and resourcefulness, and I enjoy creating new approaches.
examples: If a method feels old or rigid, I want to redesign it.
I enjoy testing new tools, workflows, or ideas just to see what happens.
I often suggest “we could do it another way” even if the old way works.
I adapt quickly by reframing a problem rather than repeating the same steps.
I prefer flexible guidelines over strict procedures.
I’m good at improvising when conditions change.
I get energy from experimenting, not from maintaining routines.
I dislike being forced into one fixed process.

items.text: Interesting possibilities lift my mood quickly; I like brainstorming with people.
examples: A new opportunity can instantly pull me out of a low mood.
I enjoy bouncing ideas back and forth to create something better.
I naturally brainstorm out loud with others.
Conversations feel best when they explore options, not only facts.
I often play devil’s advocate to open new angles.
I get excited when someone adds a surprising new idea.
I can talk about ideas for a long time without needing closure.
I feel drained by conversations that shut down possibilities quickly.

items.text: Feeling stuck (no room to change) feels especially bad to me.
examples: If life becomes repetitive, I feel restless or trapped.
I need some sense of future options to feel okay.
I’m uncomfortable when plans become too fixed too early.
I often look for exits or alternatives when a path feels like a dead end.
I dislike roles that keep me in the same routine for too long.
I feel heavy when there’s 'nothing new to look forward to.'
I can tolerate uncertainty better than feeling stuck.
I prefer keeping multiple doors open.

items.text: I strongly dislike people who are closed-minded, overly rigid, or pessimistic 'wet blankets'.
examples: I get frustrated with 'we always do it this way.'
I dislike when people reject ideas before exploring them.
I get annoyed by overly literal thinking that misses alternative meanings.
I feel limited around rigid rule-following for its own sake.
I avoid environments that punish experimentation.
I dislike pessimism that kills momentum.
I dislike nitpicking that stops exploration.
I prefer people who can entertain possibilities without fear.

items.text: I have received feedback like: scattered, impractical, inconsistent, unreliable, or unpredictable.
examples: People say I start many things but don’t always finish.
Others think I change direction too quickly.
People say I’m strong at ideas but weak at logistics.
I sometimes ignore details because I'm focused on new options.
My priorities can shift when a more interesting possibility appears.
Others think I’m unpredictable because I keep multiple routes open.
I can feel guilty about being inconsistent over time.
People say I need structure more than I admit.

items.text: I rarely have new ideas and I usually refuse to entertain new possibilities.
examples: Brainstorming feels pointless or annoying most of the time.
I prefer one proven answer, not multiple options.
I dislike discussing hypothetical possibilities.
I avoid exploring alternatives unless forced.
New approaches usually feel unnecessary.
I quickly shut down ideas that are unfamiliar.
I prefer following established methods.
I feel stressed by too many options.

items.text: I genuinely enjoy routine, repetitive practice, and logistical planning (as a preference).
examples: Repeating a stable routine feels satisfying, not boring.
I prefer maintenance and consistency over exploration.
I feel calmer when my day is predictable.
I enjoy step-by-step planning more than brainstorming.
I value reliability and procedure as the main goal.
I dislike changing plans once set.
I feel better doing what already works.
I prefer long-term consistency over experimenting.

items.text: I must think through every contingency before acting.
examples: I delay until I feel fully prepared.
I avoid improvising because it feels unsafe.
I need certainty before moving forward.
I prefer to eliminate uncertainty early.
I often overplan to avoid surprises.
I dislike acting without a detailed plan.
I feel uncomfortable with open-ended choices.
I prefer predictable steps over exploring options.

items.text: I do not relate to big-picture possibility thinking; I don’t dream big.
examples: I mostly focus on immediate practical goals.
Speculating about the future feels unrealistic.
I avoid ambitious visions; I prefer concrete tasks.
I rarely think about long-range possibilities.
I prefer what’s certain and measurable.
Dreaming about 'what could be' feels unnecessary.
I don’t enjoy abstract possibility discussions.
I focus on present reality more than future options.
